subject: Logic (RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy)

messageBody:
I will admit, I was put off by the whole focus on logic as opposed to the
point I was trying to discuss. I feel that a first time poster ought be
given a little more leeway before being picked apart on distraction issues.
If a mailing list is only for those with total intimate knowledge of the
product/terminology/concepts, then I find that a closed list. As I tried
saying with humour, forget logic steps -- try to discuss my point, if might
be right. Forget logic steps, I was trying to says "if suites are the
internal representation of testcase collections, with hierarchy, then help
the user mange them".

That said, maybe my approach/point was too contentious off the bat, and got
what it (unintentionally) deserved.

Perhaps I should have said:

"If suites are testcase hierarchy, then I don't think it is the users
job to manage them".

or better yet:

"If we accept that suites can represent dependency, then I don't think
it is the users job to manage them".

Just because I used my word not yours, doesn't mean my point was absurd.
Also, this is hardly a logical conclusion. I was attempting to establish
common ground to communicate, and then make a point.

I think this highlights much of the problem I've had communicating with
folks on this list. I think it is the "list experts" job to attempt to
understand the well intentioned ramblings of the newbies, not rip them
apart...

All in all, I need to find a way to communicate better. Clearly, what I
write is not what you read. However, I wish we could have spent the time
whittling through that rather than side issues...

regards,

Adam

>each time) but this is the crux of my argument: If (big IF) suites are
>testcase dependencies,

They absolutely, positively are NOT. I cannot stress this enough. A
TestSuite is an arbitrary collection of Test objects, and nothing more.

>then I don't think it ought be the user's job to
>manage them -- I think the framework should.

Since your hypothesis is wrong, your conclusion is not meaningful. :)
(That's logic's fault, not mine.)

> It is easy for me (outside the
>code) to say this, but I think they were a useful construct before, but
>they
>may have outlived their usefulness. I posit that suites are the existing
>hammer, so they are making things seem like a nail.

I don't understand this statement at all. A TestSuite is just a composite
collection of tests. What else do you propose to use?

> >My examples were just simple ones. Dependency can be in the eye of
the
> >beholder... :-)
>
> I don't know that it can be: dependency is or is not.
>
>I was saying dependency due to aggregation, you were saying dependency
due
>to feature. I was agreeing that users could set dependency for whatever
>reason they chose.

I see, yes.

<snip />
>
> Maybe I misunderstand Test Collectors -- point me to something to
>learn more, if you don't mind
> -- but don't they just create TestSuite objects?
>
>Unfortunately I don't have that information, I know they scan classpaths
>and
>match class patterns (e.g. *Test*). I assume they build a testsuite (or
>collection of such) but I don't know, sorry. Taking a brief look at some
>ant
>code they may even use an array/enumeration of testcases & their own
>runner,
>but I can't be sure.

The bottom line is that the mechanism is essentially the same as a
TestSuite, and a TestSuite is just a collection!

> Your way to declare a test suite is already supported by JUnit and
a
>little cute refactoring.
>
> Consider the AllTests pattern. I can reduce it to a collection of
>AllTests or TestCase class names with a little neat refactoring. Then I
>can
>use that little engine to store AllTests as text. The next step is to
>generate that text by doing a directory scan. Now I have a TestSuite
>builder
>that build tests from a part of the file system.
>
> I did nothing to change JUnit. I just decorated it. Does it belong
in
>the framework? I don't think so. That's a question of taste, in my
opinion.
>
>Great explanation of your position, and good summary of the crux of this
>discussion as it stands. My views to follow.
>
>So I think we understand each other quite well -- I just don't understand
>why you think this feature you suggest should be part of the framework?
Why
>isn't it a candidate for JUnit-addons or something like that?
>
>A few responses:
>
>1) Perhaps set the clock back. What say the original implementation had
>test
>case dependency, not test suites. Who is to say that suites warrant
>inclusion but dependencies do not? Maybe suites must stay for backwards
>compatibility (although I feel they are declining in usage) but why
>oughtn't
>dependency be there?

If you haven't already, read Kent Beck's original paper where he develops
SUnit. Perhaps some insight from there will help.

Your underlying hypothesis appears to be this:

If class A depends on B, then there exist tests T(A) that test A and tests
T(B) that test B such that T(A) depends on T(B).

It is on this basis that you want JUnit to manage those dependencies. I
claim first that JUnit can't, and second that JUnit shouldn't.

1. JUnit can't manage the dependencies without human intervention.
2. JUnit shouldn't manage the dependencies because they are not universal.

I do not view dependencies the way you do. What we have in common, though,
is that we each need to be able to execute different collections of tests at
different times. This is why the former is not a part of the framework and
the latter is. That is the essence of framework. What you want to build is a
tool. So build it.

>2) I think dependency needs to be managed on the testcase, hence be an
>optional aspect of that class. I think separating this out into a
separate
>structure (like suite) is a recipe for rust. ***This is why I think it
>needs
>to be part of the framework, not an add on.***

Disagree. I don't want that feature. I'm sure I'm not alone (Dave?). For
that reason, adding it to the framework makes the framework noisy. A
framework ought to include what's needed for universal solutions and nothing
more. Everything else is a tool.

>3) Given test collectors (classpath/directory scanners) -- and given
things
>like Eclipse testcase wizards --- I believe suites are fading out of
>consciousness. As such, I think it is less to learn to say "my testcase
>depends upon these testcases" than learn a the testsuite concept.

Get this straight: TEST CASE DEPENDENCY IS EVIL. Test cases should be as
independent as possible. It should be possible to select a number of tests
and just run them. JUnit supports that. You can build your TestSuite however
you want. The fact that there aren't better tools for this surprises me.

This mailing list has several messages showing people scratching their
heads over which tests to run instead of just creating a TestSuite with the
tests they want. It's like THEY DON'T REALIZE that a TestSuite can contain
any tests they want -- even if they belong to completely different TestCase
objects, and so on. They are in jail: their view is narrowed artificially by
not seeing the simplicity of TestSuite: it's just a collection of tests.
Collect 'em however you want.

You want to collect 'em by test case dependency -- however *YOU* define
it -- then go write the code to do it. It ain't that hard. It still doesn't
belong in the framework, because IT IS NOT UNIVERSAL USAGE. It is a narrow
view of how to put tests together.

You see Test Collectors as a replacement for TestSuite objects. With
respect, that's absurd, unless the JUnit test runner is not adequate for
their task. Still, why they decide to reinvent the wheel, I can't imagine.

>4) I believe (IMHO -- w/ no market research, just based on projects I
know)
>that dependency has great user benefit than manual test suite. As such,
I'd
>like it in the framework to aid the most users.

If you need to collect tests based on your notion of dependency, then you
would be a complete idiot to continue maintaining test suites manually.
Eventually you should automate that work. Why do you insist on comparing
automated tasks to manual ones?

>Remember that my goal -- Kent's goal, too -- is to keep JUnit very tight
>and
>small. It should provide just enough for everyone, rather than a glut of
>features that have limited use. The less to learn, the better. If you
need
>more, grab add-on package X, add-on package Y and add-on package Z.
>
>I can understand that goal, and I might agree w/ it academically. That
>said,
>I think product purity comes (a close) second to usability. And even with
>that said, I don't see how your goal counters what I suggested & doesn't
>fit
>it.

Because your need is not my need, so don't pollute JUnit with things that
only some people need. That's not a framework.

> Also, the more magic in the package, the less the users need to
learn
>to use it. I want them to know what they're doing.
>
>My goal is better testing through easier test management, easier test
>result
>analysis. That said, I don't see how the approach I am suggesting doesn't
>fit this.

So build it. I'm sure people will use it. It doesn't belong in the
framework.

>BTW: Long before the end of this mail I've started to realize that this
>whole e-mail chain is an academic exercise, unlikely to result in change.
>JUnit still rocks, and I use it fervently, this was just a random thought
>that seemed to feel like an epiphany so I posted it...

Well, in general, JUnit doesn't change much. That's intentional. That's
why we have projects like JUnit-addons, GSBase and so on.

You feel a need. If no-one has implemented it, then it's up to you. Either
way, it does not have universal appeal, so it does not belong in the
framework. That's all. It's very, very simple.

Take care. I think we're done here. :)
